title: Eagle vs. drone and Trudeau meets Trump: The week in pictures - World - CBC News
text:
Eagle vs. drone and Trudeau meets Trump: The week in pictures Top images from around the world for Feb. 11-17 CBC News Posted: Feb 18, 2017 5:00 AM ET Last Updated: Feb 18, 2017 5:00 AM ET 
Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and U.S. President Donald Trump had their first official meeting in Washington this week. The two leaders found common ground on key issues such as boosting commerce and military co-operation, but staked out very different stands on immigration policy. Scroll down for a look at some more of this week's top news pictures from around the world. (Jason Burles/CBC) Hundreds arrived in Nepal to celebrate the birthday of Shiva. 
Sadhus, or holy men, rest upon arrival for the upcoming Hindu festival Maha Shivaratri at the Pashupatinath Temple in Kathmandu, Nepal, on Friday. Hundreds of Sadhus from across the country and neighbouring India arrived this week to celebrate the birthday of Shiva — the god of creation and destruction — which falls on Feb. 24. (Narendra Shrestha/EPA) A beautiful day for feeding the birds in Macedonia. 
A girl feeds gulls on the shores of Lake Ohrid in Macedonia on Wednesday. (Ognen Teofilovski/Reuters) Torrential floods hit parts of Indonesia. 
A child sits on a chair in his flooded home in the Sidakaton district in Tegal, Indonesia, on Thursday. Thousands were left homeless after days of torrential rain triggered floods and deadly landslides throughout the country. (Antara Foto/Oky Lukmansyah/Reuters) Flamingos put some heart into Valentine's Day. 
Greater flamingos create a heart-shape — are they kissing or fighting? — at the Ramat Gan Safari near Tel Aviv, Israel, on Valentine's Day. (Abir Sultan/EPA) While newlyweds in Iraq held a foam party. 
Iraqi newlyweds who fled violence in Mosul are showered in foam during their wedding party at Khazer camp on Thursday. (Zohra Bensemra/Reuters) There were some ominous clouds in the West Bank. 
Girls walk in a playground on a stormy day in the Israeli settlement of Beitar Illit in the occupied West Bank. (Amir Cohen/Reuters) And a huge blizzard blanketed Atlantic Canada with snow. 
It was a wild week of winter weather for people in Atlantic Canada as a powerful low-pressure system brought heavy snow and strong winds to the Maritimes less than two days after a record-setting nor'easter. (Nancy Waugh/CBC) Violence erupted on the streets of Bahrain. 
A protester throws a Molotov cocktail at a riot police armoured personnel carrier while a tear gas canister is fired from the vehicle during a demonstration in Manama, Bahrain, to mark the sixth anniversary of the Feb. 14 uprising. (Hamad I Mohammed/Reuters) More than 2,800 dogs competed in the Westminster dog show. 
America's top dog was crowned Tuesday at the 141st Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show in New York. Rumor, a five-year-old German shepherd, came out of retirement to win best in show after narrowly missing out on the prize last year. 
Rumor beat out a Norwegian elkhound, a pekinese (like the adorable little guy seen below), a miniature poodle, an Irish setter, a boxer and a Norwich terrier in the final ring. (Justin Lane/EPA) Nearly 200,000 people were evacuated from homes near the Oroville Dam. 
Almost overnight, the Oroville Dam in California gained worldwide attention when authorities evacuated nearby towns, affecting almost 200,000 people, over fears that the emergency spillway was in danger of failing. Engineers spotted a hole in the spillway, which they feared could have failed within an hour. 
The evacuation order was lifted by authorities on Tuesday, although residents were warned "to be vigilant." (California Department of Water Resources/William Croyle/Reuters) A golden Cee Lo Green showed up at the Grammys. 
The musician and former judge on The Voice showed up in a bizarre golden face mask and gown on Sunday night. The costume instantly sparked an internet meme likening it to a Ferrero Rocher chocolate and C-3PO. (Mario Anzuoni/Reuters) And Adele performed a moving tribute to George Michael. 
This year's Grammy Awards belonged to Adele , who put on two memorable performances and took home hardware in all five categories in which she was nominated, including song, record and album of the year. 
The British songstress transformed Michael's 1996 hit Fastlove from a disco-tinged dance track to a melancholy memorial. But the performance got off to a rocky start. It wasn't clear if it was a technical issue, or if she flubbed a few notes, but the singer stopped, swore, apologized for swearing and restarted. 
"I can't mess this up for him," she said. Any delay was quickly forgiven. Several in the crowd, including Rihanna, could be seen wiping away tears (Kevin Winter/Getty Images for NARAS) Nature put on a show in Indonesia. 
The Mount Sinabung volcano spews smoke and ash as seen from Karo district in North Sumatra province, Feb. 11. Activity levels have increased in the past week, with Sinabung shooting hot ash clouds into the sky dozens of times, according to the local volcano monitoring agency. (ATAR/AFP/Getty Images) Carnival kicked off in Venice. 
Venice's world famous carnival starts every year around two weeks before Ash Wednesday and ends on Shrove Tuesday. Carnival means "farewell to meat" and the pre-Lent festival is celebrated throughout Italy. This year's celebration runs Feb. 11-28. (Tony Gentile/Reuters) And an eagle took down a drone from the sky. 
Eagles are being trained by the French air force to bring down remote-controlled drones that enter urban airspace where they aren't permitted to fly. The birds are trained to see the drones as prey and receive meat as a reward for bringing down a drone. The use of eagles was prompted after drones flew over a French presidential palace in 2015 and sensitive military sites in 2016. (Regis Duvignau/Reuters) Report Typo or Error Send Feedback
